content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a rational human player, I would aim to maximize my earnings over the 75 rounds of the game. To do this, I will consider each possible strategy for my opponent:

1. My opponent always picks R (R-strategy): In this case, I should choose B in round 1 to get 40$ immediately. Then, in every subsequent round, if my opponent sticks with their R-strategy, they will earn 0$, and I will earn 45$. However, I can only do this once, because after that, if I keep choosing B, my opponent will switch to an R-strategy, earning them 45$ every time and leaving me with 0$. So I need a strategy to make them deviate from their R-strategy at some point.

2. My opponent always picks B (B-strategy): If my opponent follows a B-strategy, I should pick R in round 1 to earn 45$ immediately. Then, since they will choose B in response, I will earn 0$ in round 2. Now, if I switch to a B-strategy and they stick with their B-strategy, I will earn 20$ in each of the remaining rounds. However, this would result in a lower overall payoff than if I could make them deviate from their B-strategy at some point.

3. My opponent adapts their strategy based on my choices: This is the most complex scenario, as it assumes that my opponent is able to anticipate and adapt to my strategy. In this case, I need a strategy that keeps my opponent guessing, so they cannot consistently predict my choice. One possible approach could be to alternate between R and B in a predictable pattern (e.g., R-B-R-B...), which may make it difficult for my opponent to anticipate my next move. However, this is still not the optimal strategy, as there may exist a more profitable pattern or even a mixed strategy that could outperform alternating R and B consistently.

In conclusion, given the constraints of the game, I would opt for an approach where I start by choosing R in round 1 to earn 45$ immediately. Then, depending on my opponent's response, I will either switch to a B-strategy (if they pick R) or continue with my R-B alternation pattern (if they pick B). This strategy allows me to maximize my earnings in the early rounds while keeping some uncertainty about my future choices, which may make it difficult for my opponent to devise an optimal counter-strategy. I will append my choice as follows: {R}
